article.title: Embedded Binaries and Their Dense Cores

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue contour in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The 80% flux contour of the dense core.
The 50% flux contour of the dense core.
The location of molecular outflows.
The boundary of the larger molecular cloud complex.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows an example of what type of core in Perseus?
choices: A Class 0 core
A Class I core
A starless core
A protostellar envelope

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 3, what is the general trend observed for Class I binaries compared to Class 0 binaries in terms of their separation?
choices: Class I binaries have similar separations to Class 0 binaries.
Class I binaries have a wider range of separations than Class 0 binaries.
Class I binaries tend to have tighter separations than Class 0 binaries.
Class I binaries show no correlation between their separation and core size.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 investigates the relationship between binary separation and their alignment with the parent core\'s long axis. What trend is observed for binaries with separations greater than ~500 au?
choices: They show no preferred alignment.
They tend to be perpendicular to the core\'s long axis.
They tend to be aligned with the core\'s long axis.
They show a random distribution with no clear trend.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model in Table 4 best explains the observed populations of embedded binary systems in Perseus, indicated by the lowest  Ï‡2 value?
choices: wi s
wti b
w sb
wti sb
